Description: Glass flask in the form of a pomegranate. Clear brown with opaque white, opaque light blue and opaque orange trails. Splayed rim formed by six triangular, pointed calyx-tips, bent outwards; cylindrical neck joining shoulder in curve; almost spherical body with rounded bottom. On body two groups of opaque combed trails: (a) on upper half, three trails, light blue, orange, and white, combed into upright festoons; (b) on lower half, three trails, light blue, orange, and white, combed into inverted festoons. Core-formed and tooled, trails marvered and combed.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Turner Bequest Excavations, Enkomi
Curator's comments: BM Glass Murray et al. 1900, 24, 35, fig. 63. Fossing 1940, 28 (mention only). Astrom 1967, 58, 125 (=id. 1972, 530, 597). Masterpieces 1968, 20, no. 8. Barag 1970, 185.
Bibliographic references: Glass / Catalogue of Greek and Roman Glass in the British Museum (14)
Murray, Smith and Walters 1900 / Excavations in Cyprus (p.23-4,35, Fig 63)
Peltenburg 1986 / Ramesside Egypt and Cyprus (P. 153, No. 1)
Tait 1991 / Five Thousand Years of Glass (fig.20, p.25)
Harden et al 1968 / Masterpieces of Glass (8)
Exhibition history: Exhibited: 2008-2009 18 Nov-15 Mar, New York, Metropolitan Museum of Art, 'Beyond Babylon: Art, Trade, and Diplomacy in the Second Millennium B.C.'
Condition: Broken and mended, one side and bottom of body restored in plaster; two calyx-tips missing. Some dulling, no weathering.
